metadata.titleEn: Environmental index data set of Ganzi loess profile  in Western Sichuan Plateau
metadata.description: This data is the magnetism, grain size, chromaticity, diffuse reflectance spectral goethite / hematite peak height data, organic matter stable carbon isotope data of loess-paleosol sequence in Ganzi section (XS) in the east of Tibetan Plateau (TP). We measured the magnetic susceptibility and grain size of the section (10 m) at an interval of 2.5 cm, measured the non-hysteresis remanence and isothermal remanence data at an interval of 5 cm, and provided 5 sets of hysteresis loop measurement results. Total organic carbon (TOC) and organic carbon isotopes were measured at 10 cm and 20 cm intervals respectively. The experimental analysis of magnetic susceptibility was completed at the Key Laboratory of Western China's Environmental Systems (Ministry of Education), Lanzhou University, China. The soil δ13Corgmeasurements were conducted at the State Key Laboratory of Grassland Agro-ecosystems (SKLGAE), Lanzhou University. And the analysis of remanence and hysteresis loop was completed at the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Chromaticity analysis was carried out in the State Key Laboratory of Loess and Quaternary Geology. The magnetic susceptibility is measured by Bartington MS2 magnetic susceptibility meter, the non-hysteresis remanence is measured by American ASCIM-10-30 pulse magnetometer and molspin minispin small rotation magnetometer, and the isothermal remanence is measured by ASCIM-10-30 pulse magnetometer, 2g-755 superconducting magnetometer and JR-6A rotation magnetometer; he grain size data were measured by a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser diffractometer; The chromaticity was determined by CM-700d spectrophotometer. The δ13Corgvalues were analyzed using a MAT-253 isotope ratio mass spectrometer. This data provides an understanding of the magnetic properties and chromaticity variation characteristics of the loess sequence in the eastern TP since the last interglacial period, and plays an important role in the research of the paleoenvironment and paleoclimate in the eastern TP and its relationship with the surrounding atmospheric circulation.
metadata.instructions: Magnetism, grain size, chromaticity, diffuse reflectance, organic matter stable carbon isotope data of Ganzi XS section are stored in CSV format, and the file name are “Chromaticity , first and second derivative peaks of diffuse reflectance spectradata of XS Section”、“Hysteresis loop data of XS section”、“Magnetic parameters of XS section”、“Magnetic susceptibility and Grain size of  XS section”、 “Total organic carbon and organic matter stable carbon isotope data of XS section”, respectively.

background: The stable carbon isotope (δ13Corg) composition of soil organic matter (SOM) is closely related to vegetation and soil pedogenic processes and is one of the main tools used to understand the component processes of the terrestrial carbon cycle. As the δ13Corg composition of a given plant is controlled by the environmental conditions as well as the vegetation type, the δ13Corg composition of loess–paleosol sequences has been widely used as a valuable indicator to reconstruct past environments and the paleoecology of the Chinese Loess Plateau (CLP) and other regions. Numerous studies have shown that the δ13Corg values in paleosols are more positive than those in loess deposits. However, in eastern and southeastern Europe, central Asia, and the northwestern CLP, the loess δ13Corg values exhibit opposite patterns with more negative values during paleosol periods than those during loess accumulation periods since the last interglacial (LIG). The Tibetan Plateau (TP) has a strong influence on regional and global climate change due to its large area and high elevation. Aeolian loess is widely distributed on the TP and provides a crucial archive for understanding the evolution of the Indian monsoon and paleoenvironments of the TP. It has been inferred from a large dataset of the δ13C composition of modern soils on the TP that the mean annual precipitation (MAP) and mean annual temperature (MAT) are the main factors controlling the distribution of vegetation type on the TP, which causes the variation in δ13C composition of modern soils at any given altitude.
research objective: We conducted detailed δ13Corg and total organic carbon analyses of the Ganzi loess sequence on the eastern TP since the last interglacial (LIG). In the present research, we choose a typical loess section near Ganzi County on the eastern TP for detailed δ13Corg analysis. By combining our results with other environmental proxies, we discuss the variation characteristics of loess δ13Corg values during the last glacial–interglacial cycle and its environmental implications. The results of this study will deepen our understanding of the evolution of the paleoenvironment on the eastern TP.
methods: The studied section was the XS section (99°59′E, 31°37′N), which is located in the northwestern region of Ganzi County at an elevation of 3400 m above sea level (a.s.l). Five samples for optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) dating were taken by hammering stainless steel tubes into the fresh outcrop near the stratigraphic boundary. Bulk samples were collected at 2.5 cm intervals for the subsequent measurement of paleoenvironment proxies. For the samples taken at a depth of 1 m, 3 m, and 5 m, medium quartz grains (38–63 μm) were purified for OSL dating and were prepared following the methods of Lai et al. (2007). Quartz OSL dating with a standard single aliquot regenerative-dose protocol was performed using a Lexsyg research automatic TL/OSL reader at the Laboratory of the Institute of Mountain Hazards and Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences. For the two bottom samples with depths at 7.5 m and 10 m, the quartz luminescence signal was close to saturation, which would have led to the underestimation of the ages of the samples. Thus, the post-infrared (IR)–IR stimulated luminescence (SL) (pIR–IRSL) dating on coarse grains of K-rich feldspar were conducted using an automated Risø TL/OSL reader at Lanzhou University. The soil δ13Corg measurements were conducted at the State Key Laboratory of Grassland Agro-ecosystems (SKLGAE), Lanzhou University. Before measurement, all air-dried loess samples were ground into a uniform size powder (>200 mesh) after removal of modern rootlets. Subsamples of ~3 g were treated with 10% hydrochloric acid (HCl) for 24 h to remove inorganic carbon completely and then oven-dried at 40 °C after thorough rinsing with distilled water. Subsequently, 3–5 mg subsamples were weighed and placed in a tin cup for analysis. Total organic carbon (TOC) and magnetic susceptibility (MS) measurements were carried out at the Key Laboratory of Western China’s Environmental Systems (Ministry of Education), Lanzhou University. Diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were measured at the Institute of Earth Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences, in Xi'an.
findings: The δ13Corg values of loess during glacial periods were lower than those during interglacial periods, with more negative values associated with the cold stages since the LIG on the eastern TP. The reconstruction of vegetation from the δ13Corg data indicated that C3/C4 mixed vegetation was dominated by C3 vegetation, and that the relative abundance of C4 vegetation during the glacial stages was much lower than that during MIS 5 and MIS 3. The high relative abundance of C4 plants during MIS 5 and MIS 3 suggested an increased proportion of C4 plants during the warm period. Since the LIG, the change in the abundance of C3/C4 vegetation in the Ganzi region has been mainly controlled by climate change at the glacial–interglacial scale. The combined effect of temperature, precipitation, and atmospheric CO2 caused changes in the paleovegetation on the eastern TP.

Example.Question: Please provide an example of a technique used to date loess sequences and its challenges.
Example.Answer: Optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) dating was used for quartz grains, with medium quartz grains (38–63 μm) purified and prepared following specific methods. For samples where the quartz luminescence signal was close to saturation, post-infrared (IR)–IR stimulated luminescence (SL) (pIR–IRSL) dating on coarse grains of K-rich feldspar was conducted. The challenge with the quartz luminescence signal being close to saturation could lead to the underestimation of the ages of the samples.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'δ13Corg composition' in the context of paleoclimate studies?
Definition.Answer: The δ13Corg composition refers to the stable carbon isotope composition of soil organic matter, which is closely related to vegetation and soil pedogenic processes. It is used as a tool to understand the component processes of the terrestrial carbon cycle and to reconstruct past environments and paleoecology.

Definition.Question: What does 'pIR–IRSL dating on coarse grains of K-rich feldspar' entail in the context of geochronology?
Definition.Answer: The pIR–IRSL dating on coarse grains of K-rich feldspar involves using post-infrared infrared stimulated luminescence techniques to date sediment samples. This method is particularly used when quartz luminescence signals are close to saturation, providing alternative age estimations for geological samples.

Comparison.Question: How do the magnetic susceptibility measurement techniques compare to the methods used for δ13Corg analysis in terms of equipment and procedures?
Comparison.Answer: Magnetic susceptibility measurements utilize the Bartington MS2 magnetic susceptibility meter, while δ13Corg analysis employs the MAT-253 isotope ratio mass spectrometer. Magnetic susceptibility is measured at 2.5 cm intervals and involves non-destructive magnetic measurements, whereas δ13Corg analysis requires chemical treatment of samples to remove inorganic carbon before isotope measurement.

Interpretation.Question: How can variations in δ13Corg values observed in loess-paleosol sequences be interpreted to reflect past environmental changes in the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: Variations in δ13Corg values in loess-paleosol sequences can indicate changes in vegetation types and environmental conditions on the Tibetan Plateau. More positive δ13Corg values in paleosols compared to loess deposits suggest shifts in dominant vegetation, possibly driven by climate factors such as temperature and precipitation. These variations reflect the influence of glacial and interglacial periods on paleovegetation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for different data collection intervals when measuring magnetic susceptibility and organic carbon in loess-paleosol sequences?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for different data collection intervals is caused by the specific characteristics and research objectives associated with each type of data. Magnetic susceptibility and grain size data are measured at more frequent intervals (2.5 cm) to capture fine-scale variations, while total organic carbon and isotopic measurements are taken at larger intervals (10 cm and 20 cm) due to their relatively stable nature over larger spans.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to use multiple types of instruments for measuring magnetic and optical data in the analysis of loess-paleosol sequences?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Using multiple types of instruments is important because it allows for a comprehensive analysis of different properties of the material. Instruments like the Bartington MS2 for magnetic susceptibility and the CM-700d spectrophotometer for colorimetry provide specific insights into the magnetic and optical properties, respectively, which are crucial for understanding the environmental and climatic conditions reflected in the loess-paleosol sequences.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the choice of using quartz OSL dating and pIR-IRSL dating methods in paleoenvironmental studies of the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The choice between quartz OSL dating and pIR-IRSL dating methods is influenced by the characteristics of the samples and the depth of the sediment layers. Quartz OSL is typically used when medium quartz grains are available and suitable for dating, while pIR-IRSL is chosen for deeper layers or when quartz luminescence signals approach saturation, as it helps avoid age underestimation in such conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind conducting detailed δ13Corg and total organic carbon analyses in loess sequences on the eastern Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives are to understand the variation characteristics of loess δ13Corg values during the last glacial–interglacial cycle and its environmental implications, deepening the understanding of the evolution of the paleoenvironment on the eastern Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it significant to measure paleoenvironment proxies at specific intervals in loess-paleosol sequences?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Measuring paleoenvironment proxies at specific intervals, such as 2.5 cm for bulk samples, allows for detailed analysis of environmental changes over time, helping to reconstruct past environments and understand the paleoecology, particularly in regions like the Tibetan Plateau.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental techniques are employed to measure magnetic properties and grain size in loess samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Magnetic susceptibility is measured using a Bartington MS2 magnetic susceptibility meter, while grain size data is determined using a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser particle size analyzer. Additionally, non-hysteretic remanent magnetization is measured using ASCIM-10-30 pulse magnetometers and Molspin Minispin magnetometers.

Enablement.Question: What technologies are used to enable the precise measurement of magnetic susceptibility and grain size in loess-paleosol sequences on the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Magnetic susceptibility is measured using a Bartington MS2 magnetic susceptibility meter, and grain size data is obtained using a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser particle size analyzer.

Enablement.Question: How do isotopic ratio mass spectrometers facilitate the analysis of stable carbon isotopes in soil organic matter?
Enablement.Answer: The MAT-253 isotope ratio mass spectrometer is used to measure the δ13Corg of samples, allowing for detailed analysis of stable carbon isotopes in soil organic matter.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the dating of loess deposits in the eastern Tibetan Plateau using optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) techniques?
Enablement.Answer: Quartz OSL dating is performed using a standard single aliquot regenerative-dose protocol with the Lexsyg research automatic TL/OSL reader, and post-infrared (IR)–IR stimulated luminescence (SL) dating on coarse grains of K-rich feldspar is conducted using an automated Risø TL/OSL reader.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected relationship between δ13Corg values and glacial-interglacial periods be different in various regions, and how can data collection methods account for these differences?
Expectation.Answer: The δ13Corg values exhibit different patterns in various regions due to factors like regional climate influences, vegetation types, and soil processes. Data collection methods that consider these regional characteristics, such as using multiple environmental proxies and detailed δ13Corg analysis, can help account for these differences.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of the data collection methods used for stable carbon isotope analyses in understanding past environmental conditions on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods for stable carbon isotope analyses, such as detailed δ13Corg and total organic carbon measurements, are effective in reconstructing past environmental conditions on the Tibetan Plateau. These methods, when combined with other environmental proxies, provide valuable insights into the variation characteristics of loess δ13Corg values during different climatic periods, thereby enhancing our understanding of paleoenvironmental changes.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential avenues for expanding datasets related to magnetic susceptibility and diffuse reflectance spectra in loess-paleosol research?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential avenues for expanding datasets in this research area include increasing the spatial coverage of sampling sites across different regions of the Tibetan Plateau to capture diverse environmental conditions. Additionally, integrating these datasets with other geological and climatic proxies could provide a more comprehensive understanding of environmental changes over time. Technological advancements in measurement instruments could also enhance the precision and scope of data collection.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the δ13Corg values are used to reconstruct past environments and what makes them a reliable indicator in this context.
Assertion.Answer: The δ13Corg composition of soil organic matter is closely related to vegetation and soil pedogenic processes. It is influenced by environmental conditions and vegetation types, making it a valuable indicator for reconstructing past environments and paleoecology, as shown in various regions including the Chinese Loess Plateau and the Tibetan Plateau.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the methodology used for dating loess samples and why certain dating techniques are chosen over others.
Assertion.Answer: Optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) and post-infrared (IR)–IR stimulated luminescence (SL) dating techniques are used based on the characteristics of the samples. Medium quartz grains and K-rich feldspar are used for OSL and pIR–IRSL dating respectively, as they provide reliable age estimation considering the luminescence signal saturation issues in some samples.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how different environmental proxies are combined to interpret the paleoenvironmental conditions on the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Environmental proxies such as δ13Corg values, total organic carbon, and magnetic susceptibility are measured at high-resolution intervals and combined with data from diffuse reflectance spectra to infer past climate conditions, vegetation types, and changes over glacial–interglacial cycles, providing a comprehensive view of paleoenvironmental conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methods used for collecting and analyzing the δ13Corg and total organic carbon data in loess sequences.
Request/Directive.Answer: The soil δ13Corg measurements were conducted at the State Key Laboratory of Grassland Agro-ecosystems, Lanzhou University. After air-drying the loess samples, they were ground into uniform size powder (>200 mesh) after removal of modern rootlets. Subsamples of approximately 3 g were treated with 10% hydrochloric acid (HCl) for 24 hours to remove inorganic carbon completely and then oven-dried at 40°C after thorough rinsing with distilled water. Subsequently, 3–5 mg subsamples were weighed and placed in a tin cup for analysis. Total organic carbon (TOC) measurements were carried out at the Key Laboratory of Western China’s Environmental Systems, Ministry of Education, Lanzhou University.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that can complement the understanding of paleoenvironmental changes in the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The dataset contains information on magnetic data, grain size, colorimetry data, diffuse reflectance spectra, and stable carbon isotope data from loess-paleosol sequences on the eastern Tibetan Plateau. This data provides insights into magnetic properties and color variations, which play a crucial role in understanding past environments and climate dynamics in the region.
